PROJECT SUMMARY
The University of Miami Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (RSMAS) proposes to operate the R/V Walton Smith in support of NSF funded research in CY 2005. This is a five-year cooperative agreement, and funding for the years 2006-2009 will be renegotiated and will depend on the number of days at sea in support of NSF-funded research programs requiring the use of an Oceanographic platform. The Walton Smith is owned by the University of Miami and is a 96-foot catamaran research vessel. Its prime area of operations is off coastal Florida waters, both in the Atlantic and in the Gulf of Mexico, and the Bahamas. In CY 2005 the ship will support NSF funded researchers for 102 days at sea, out of a 196 day schedule. The primary NSF-funded research projects that will use this ship as their platform are funded from the areas of biological and chemical oceanography

Intellectual and Technical Merit
The Walton Smith is a modern, well equipped research vessel with an experienced and well-trained crew. The research being conducted on the Walton Smith will contribute to the understanding of important issues in its area of operations. The billfish research is the first sustained study of the fish, and it will look at eh source, opportunities, and fate of billfish larvae. A biocomplexity study in the Bahamas will contribute the understanding of a three billion year old ecosystem and its modern analogues. Studies will also be conducted on harmful algal blooms, and population dynamics that contribute to these blooms.

Broader impacts
Ship operations play a vital role at Rosenstiel and results in information and research that contributes significantly to the School's outreach program. The School is committed to improving scientific and environmental literacy among students and adults, both regionally as well as nationwide. Sample programs follow:
1 .During the summer months, the school runs several teacher training programs and collaborates with the Miami Museum of Science in a government sponsored education program for students at risk.
2. The university has partnered with Royal Caribbean, NOAA, ONR, NASA, and NSF to create a research and education program aboard the Explorer of the Sea. As well as gathering data, the program provides talks on current research topics at Rosenstiel to passengers on the ship.
3. Students, both graduate and undergraduate, from RSMAS, the University of South Florida, Florida International University, and the University of Miami Marine Science Programs routinely participate as members of the ship's science party. This provides opportunities for these students to participate in "at sea" oceanography.

Project Outcomes Report – 0504725 Ship Operations CY2005 – CY2009 University of Miami Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science

The University of Miami Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science owns and operates the Research Vessel F.G. Walton Smith. This vessel is a 96’ long by 40’ wide aluminum catamaran research vessel with a host of state of the art atmospheric and seawater sensors and instrumentation and is designed to explore the coastal and near coastal waters of the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico as well as the adjacent Bahamas and Caribbean Sea.

The ship was built at Eastern Shipbuilding Group in Panama City, Florida and delivered to UM in early 2000 where she replaced the aging R/V Calanus. The 70’ monohull Calanus was built in 1970 and carried two crew and 6 scientists. The Walton Smith carries 7 crew and up to 13 scientists so she is a quite larger and more capable vessel. There is a captain, chief mate, chief engineer, second mate, assistant engineer, cook and electronics technician.

This vessel is part of the UNOLS (University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System) fleet of research vessels and operates under agreement with the National Science Foundation in support of scientific research cruises. The period of time that is covered by this report is March 1, 2005 through February 29, 2012. The contract name includes CY2005-CY2009 but this contract was extended for two more years so it actually covers 7 calendar years, CY2005-CY2011. During this time period the R/V Walton Smith conducted 167 scientific research cruises totaling 1,164 days at sea. Nearly all of these cruises were supported by Federal agencies such as the National Science Foundation NSF), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Naval Research Laboratories (NRL), and the Office of Naval Research (ONR). Approximately 70 of these cruises were conducted to measure the health (physical, biological and chemical properties) of the coastal and near coastal waters of the areas surrounding Florida including the Florida Straits, the Dry Tortugas and the Gulf coast of Florida. This is the longest accurate assessment of these areas ever conducted and is still ongoing. Other cruises in the Bahamas included the studies of Cyanobacteria (reef building bacteria), Soft Corals, Crinoids and Whales. These are often diving cruises which are supported by the Walton Smith’s advanced Nitrox diving compressor and several small boats. One Bahamas cruise involved deploying the Max Rover ROV from Oceaneering International to depths of 2500 meters. The ship also often works in conjunction with federal projects being carried on by the Naval Undersea Warfare Center and Naval Surface Warfare Center.

After April, 2010 the R/V Walton Smith would spend extensive time in the Gulf of Mexico in support of the science being conducted to investigate the effects of oil from the Deep Water Horizon (DWH) incident. She was the first federally chartered ship that was directed to embark scientists and proceed to the DWH site where the scientists were actually able to identify and track the very large subsurface oil plumes being generated through the damaged well pipe. These scientists and the Walton Smith appeared on many news programs in order to inform the public about what was being discovered concerning this disaster. Even today cruises are still being conducted by the Walton Smith to explore the current status of these effects.

When at the dock the Walton Smith offers numerous open houses and tours, especially to area academic organizations such as elementary, middle school and high school students. Many undergraduate and graduate students from the University of Miami and other institutions have also participated in a variety of cruises giving them the unique experience of conducting oceanographic research...
